inlineContent.text: Typical examples of editable widgets are [class

[class
]. It contains functions for generically manipulating
an editable widget, a large number of action signals used for key bindings,
and several signals that an application can connect to modify the behavior
of a widget.
As an example of the latter usage, by connecting the following handler to
[signal[Editable](//documentation/gtk/editable/oninserttext(flags:handler:)], an application can convert all entry
into a widget into uppercase.
The most likely scenario for implementing
on your own widget
is that you will embed a
inside a complex widget, and want to
delegate the editable functionality to that text widget.
provides some utility functions to make this easy.
In your class_init function, call [func
passing the first available property ID:
In your interface_init function for the
interface, provide
an implementation for the get_delegate vfunc that returns your text widget:
You don’t need to provide any other vfuncs. The default implementations
work by forwarding to the delegate that the
vfunc returns.
In your instance_init function, create your text widget, and then call
[method
In your dispose function, call [method
] before
destroying your text widget:
Finally, use [func
] in your
function (and similar for
), to set the editable properties:
It is important to note that if you create a
that uses
a delegate, the low level [signal[Editable](//documentation/gtk/editable/oninserttext(flags:handler:)] and
[signal[Editable](//documentation/gtk/editable/ondeletetext(flags:handler:)] signals will be propagated from the
“wrapper” editable to the delegate, but they will not be propagated from
the delegate to the “wrapper” editable, as they would cause an infinite
recursion. If you wish to connect to the [signal[Editable](//documentation/gtk/editable/oninserttext(flags:handler:)]
and [signal[Editable](//documentation/gtk/editable/ondeletetext(flags:handler:)] signals, you will need to connect
to them on the delegate obtained via [method
The
protocol exposes the methods and properties of an underlying
instance.
The default implementation of these can be found in the protocol extension below.

reference if you already have an instance you just want to use.
